definition:
A **Banach algebra** $\mathcal{A}$ is a Banach space (over $\mathbb{C}$)
with an multiplication law compatible with the norm which turns
$\mathcal{A}$ into an algebra. Compatibility with the norm means that,
for all $a,b \in \mathcal{A}$, it is the case that the following product
inequality holds:
$${\Vert ab\Vert} \leq {\Vert a\Vert}\,{\Vert b\Vert}$$

A **Banach \*-algebra** is a Banach algebra $\mathcal{A}$ with a map
${}^* \colon \mathcal{A} \to \mathcal{A}$ which satisfies the following
properties: $$\begin{aligned}
a^{**} & = & a, \\
(ab)^* & = & b^* a^*, \\
(a+b)^* & = & a^* + b^*, \\
(\lambda a)^* & = & \bar{\lambda} a^* \quad\forall\lambda\in{\mathbb{C}}, \\
{\Vert a^*\Vert} & = & {\Vert a\Vert},\end{aligned}$$

where $\bar{\lambda}$ is the complex conjugation of $\lambda$. In other
words, the operator $^*$ is an involution.

The algebra of bounded operators on a Banach space is a Banach algebra
for the operator norm.
